I'll just say that the pairing of [Leaders in assists, typically] for TEAM PLAYERS had me thinking there briefly, since my number one sport is baseball.  In baseball, a fielder gets an assist for taking part in a play which results in an out, but not being the one who gets that out.  For example, a ground ball to an infielder that is fielded and thrown to the first baseman for an out; the first baseman gets the putout, the other infielder an assist.  The other infielder isn't being magnanimous here; only the first baseman is in position to make the putout.  That's why first basemen (and catchers, who get the putout on every strikeout) always lead the league in putouts.  An outfielder gets an assist by throwing a base runner out.  He's much too far away to make the putout himself.  

Of course, in most other sports, like basketball, hockey and soccer, the player who gets an assist for making a pass is a team player because he or she doesn't try to score him/herself.  (The other player is usually in a better position to score.)

So the clue is fine, but I was a little stymied for a HOT MINUTE.

The Little Mermaid was one of the most depressing things I have ever seen in my life. The sculpture is truly beautiful, exquisitely formed, small and delicate, dreamy and romantic. However, it is besieged by mindless hoards of tourist who arrive by bus and boat, snap a selfie for their Insta and are gone in less than a minute. The air vibrates with the ugly garbage-truck-like notes of diesel engines of dozens of gaudily painted tourist buses, their line at the curb of the narrow port street long like a freight train, waiting to gobble up the thoughtless barbarians. The mob jostles to get the best angle. Many never even look at the mermaid with their own eyes, only seeing her, tiny and insignificant, in the background of their phone screens, and all she ever sees of them are their backs. Art is reduced to a being a prop, the vase of flowers in a Victorian portrait, devoid of all meaning. My wife and I would have loved to sit down and contemplate the beauty of the sculpture but we were denied the chance. We quickky left in di5gu5t, having taken this picture: https://imgur.com/a/r6IzAof Now, the grid. It was a fine puzzle. Having grown up in Worcester UK I love the American fascination with the word Worcestershire. Plenty of brits don‚Äôt know how to pronounce it either, to be fair.

WORCE =‚Äúwus‚Äù with the vowel sound similar to the ‚Äúoo‚Äù in book
STER = ‚Äústuh‚Äù
SHIRE = ‚Äúsher‚Äù
Emphasis on the WUS so 

WUS-stuh-sher 

Originally the Roman settlement was called Vertis, meaning ‚Äúlittle turn on the river‚Äù. Once the Romans left, it went through a few permutations - Vigornia, Weogornaceaster (even I won‚Äôt attempt to pronounce that one), Wirecester and finally Worcester.

Here's a limerick. possibly by Louis Untermeyer, which is only funny to those whose humor is so arcane to not be funny at all, anymore:

"There was a young curate of Salisbury
Whose manners were quite halisbury-scalisbury

Without any pampshire
Till the Vicar compelled him to walisbury."

***

Several people have commented on the fact that the formula for worcestershire sauce contains fermented anchovies. It's what gives it that rich taste that is called "umami" is Asian cuisine and American foodiespeak, and "yummi" by everyone else. Worcestershire falls into that category of fish sauces that includes garum*, the ancient Roman condiment that the ancient Romans sprinkled on everything. Recipes for its production have been preserved, and classical scholars would sit over steaming bowls of pho at their local Vietnamese restaurant, discussing how disgusting garum must have been, even whilst dipping their summer rolls into plates of nuoc cham.

FWIW, I will regularly add a dash of Chinese dark soy sauce to add umami, even to such European dishes as Beef Stroganoff and Coq au Vin. Also, it's vegan, for those who care.

*or perhaps I should write "galisbury," which might offer a clue to deciphering that stupid limerick.

"Quite some time, antonymously" is a solid clue--and it's not asking for the opposite of "quite some time," which would make it just a weird clue.  It's asking for an expression that means idiomatically more or less the opposite of what it would seem to mean literally. I grew up with the familiar bottle of Lea & Perrins' WORCESTERSHIRE sauce in our cupboard, and have never thought of it as hard to pronounce. I'd say it's hard to spell, not hard to pronounce. It's only hard to pronounce if you've only ever seen the word without hearing it.  Going from the spelling to the pronunciation is almost impossible without assistance.

But the same could be said for lots and lots of words, some of them relatively short (and simple?).

My favorite example from my own experience is "awry".  Having only come across the word in reading and never hearing it said, I assumed it was "aw-ree".  When I heard someone say "…ô-rƒ´", I chuckled inwardly.  "Surely that's wrong," I thought.
Live and learn.

I'd love to hear your favorite examples of this phenomenon.
